article.title: The Double Galaxy Cluster Abell 2465 III. X-ray and Weak-lensing Observations

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 primarily illustrate about the double galaxy cluster Abell 2465?
choices: The contrasting X-ray and optical brightness profiles of the NE and SW components.
The presence of a significant amount of hot gas bridging the NE and SW components.
The offset between the X-ray peaks and the BCGs in both the NE and SW components.
The similar morphology and size of the NE and SW components in both X-ray and optical.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information can be derived from the model fits shown in Figure 2?
choices: The presence of a cool core in the NE component, indicated by the steep central slope.
The significantly larger core radius of the NE component compared to the SW component.
The equal gas masses of the NE and SW components within the observed radius.
The absence of any slope change in the emission measure profiles of both subclusters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key difference between the NE and SW components is highlighted by the data in Table 2?
choices: The significantly higher central gas density (œÅo) in the SW component compared to the NE component.
The nearly identical gas masses (Mg) of the two subclusters within the given radius.
The significantly larger core radius (rc) of the SW component compared to the NE component.
The similar gas temperatures (not shown in the table) of the two subclusters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What characteristic of the SW sub-component is evident from the weak-lensing mass contours in Figure 7?
choices: A perfectly symmetrical mass distribution, indicative of a relaxed system.
An elongated mass distribution, potentially suggesting tidal interaction with the NE component.
A significantly lower total mass compared to the NE component.
The absence of any substructure within the SW component itself.
